title: brexit deal vote house of commons theresa may
story: Talks are stalled in Strasbourg this evening over the Northern Irish backstop as she prepares an th hour plea to MPs to avoid a humiliating Commons defeat.The PM and her aides all looked pleased when they arrived in France this evening and went into talks about how to get the Brexit deal through.But Government sources tried to play down tonights last-ditch dash, stressing that the chat did not mean a deal was definitely on the cards.The PM was expected to give a statement following talks but is still in negotiations, her deputy David Lidington said this evening.She will still hold a second vote on her Brexit deal tomorrow - and could expected to suffer a loss as the talks dragged on and on.Mr Lidington told MPs in a late night sitting in the Commons that the PM had secured legally binding changes that strengthened and improved the withdrawal agreement.EU sources said the two sides are set to agree a joint interpretative instrument which will set in law new promises on how to get out of the hated Northern Irish backstopneeded.It could also include an addition to the political declaration too - a statement on what our future relationship with the EU will look like - which will promise to work together for a free trade deal.But talks appeared to be stuck over the final point - a UK statement which would help the Attorney General change his legal advice on whether the backstop would last forever or not.Mrs Mays scramble across to Europe was accidentally slipped out by Irish foreign minister Simon Coveney earlier, who said Mrs May was going to try and finalise an agreement,thats possible.The Irish cabinet are set to meet too this evening, and the DUPs Arlene Foster is in London talking to her MPs.Brexiteer Steve Baker said this evening he was waiting to see the text of the deal, telling Sky News: We may or may not be able to support it. We will make our own decisions.If in  to  years we found ourselves trapped in the backstop, in the customs union, people would rightly curse the day we had voted for the withdrawal agreement and ask why we’d been so weak.Their group of lawyers will meet tomorrow to analyse whether they think Britain can exit the backstop or not.German Chancellor Angela Merkel had stirred hopes of a breakthrough by saying Brussels had made a “very important offer”.Meanwhile, Brussels is willing to grant an extension of Brexit talks until the end of May - but will only go beyond thattheres an election or a second referendum.Ahead of the crunch meeting today the PM was in talks with top Tories including Mr Baker, Owen Paterson, backbench boss Sir Graham Brady and Iain Duncan Smith, with speculation growing that shes going to have something substantial to bring back from the EU ahead of the vote.After Attorney General Geoffrey Cox failed to secure legally binding changes to the Irish backstop proposal last week, the PM has come under pressure to abandon the second meaningful vote on the deal.Negotiations ground to a halt over the weekend but were kickstarted again by the PM and Mr Juncker in phonecalls.Other senior figures warned theyd kick her out of officeshe chickened out of the meaningful vote.Today Brexit minister Robin Walker confirmed today the vote would go ahead as originally planned - as well as the two other votes on delaying Brexit and going for No Deal,her deal is rejected.And Mr Cox will publish his full legal advice tomorrow morning before the start of debate on the deal.Last month Mrs May promised to hold the binding vote on her deal by March  - and said thatshe lost, MPs would be able to decide what happens next.Ex-minister Nick Boles hinted he would vote to bring down the Government and trigger a snap electionthe PM went back on her vow.He tweeted: I am sure that the Prime Minister will honour these three commitments. If she doesnt she will forfeit the confidence of the House of Commons.Leading moderates have called on the PM to quither strategy flops this week.Today senior Tory George Freeman said Mrs Mays days were numbered evenshe does pull off a victory in tomorrows vote.He told the BBC: I hope the Prime Minister can get withdrawal through and then I do think we need to choose a new leader for a new generation with a new vision of a conservativism that can make sense of Brexit and reinspire and reunite the nation.Allowing the Commons to choose between No Deal and a Brexit delay could tear the Government apart and see at least a dozen ministers resign.Last night Health Minister Steve Brine said he would quittold to vote for a No Deal Brexit.He called on Mrs May to offer Tory MPs a free votethe motion does take place.David Cameron today backed the PMs strategy - but warned against a possible No Deal.Questioned outside his London home, the former Prime Minister said: I support the Prime Minister and I think she is doing the right thing seeking a partnership deal with the EU, thats the right approach.And he added: I dont think No Deal is a good idea at all.

title: business brexit deal delay house of commons
story: Industry groups told The Sun businesses are desperate for a resolution to the Brexit debate.They expressed support for Theresa Mays Brexit deal so Britain can finally leave the EU on March .And they suggested the best way to rule out a chaotic No Deal was to vote for the withdrawal agreement in tomorrows crunch Commons showdown.A spokesman for the Confederation of British Industry said: If a deal is secured, that would at least give businesses the certainty theyre desperate for.The Institute of Directors added: A majority of our members want to avoid No Deal - that means supporting Mays deal, because thats the only way to do it.Stephen Jones, head of UK Finance, told The Sun: “Time is running out to avoid a chaotic No Deal Brexit that would do signicant damage to the UK economy.Every day of uncertainty means more damage to investment, jobs and business confidence.And Mike Cherry of the Federation of Small Businesses said: “Over the next week, small businesses need to see Parliament come together and map a credible route towards a pro-business deal that delivers the transition period they crave.There is no more time for political games.If the PMs deal is defeated today, the Commons is expected to vote for a delay to Brexit of up to three months.But bosses warned a delay is pointlessit means just kicking the can down the road.A spokesman for the British Chambers of Commerce said: It cant just be delay for the sake of delay, it has to be with an idea of what happens next.The British Retail Consortium said retail firms are spending cash on contingency plans because they dont know what shape Brexit will take.The group said: A delay would increase theof time theyre spending that money to prepare for No Deal.Tomorrow the House of Commons will vote on whether to accept the Prime Ministers deal.If it is defeated, MPs will then be given the choice between leaving with No Deal on March , or delaying Brexit instead.

title: theresa may uses bible reading to send barbed message to eu that they need a good brexit deal as well
story: The PM used a reading at Westminster Abbeys Commonwealth Day service to stress the importance of the body working together with no ision.She told an audience today in central London: The body is not made up of one part but of many.Just hours before she jetted off to Strasbourg she read  Corinthians.It said: The eye cannot say to the hand, I don’t need you! And the head cannot say to the feet, I don’t need you!On the contrary, those parts of the body that seem to be weaker are indispensable, and the parts that we think are less honourable we treat with special honour.But God has put the body together, giving greater honour to the parts that lacked it,  so that there should be no ision in the body, but that its parts should have equal concern for each other.If one part suffers, every part suffers with itone part is honoured, every part rejoices with it.It was seen as a coded message for the EU to compromise on Brexit as talks go down to the wire.The PM will have last ditch chats with EU boss Jean Claude Juncker tonight, raising hopes that a deal will be on the cards to give to MPs before tomorrows vote.The Government has said the Brexit votes will take place as planned tomorrow, but the PM doesnt have anything new to offer. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit explained brussels eu theresa may corbyn
story: But what does it meanBritain leaves the European Union without a deal  Heres what we know about this fast-changing situation.A No Deal departure from the European Union means leaving without formal arrangements for the future relationship or any transition period.Currently Britains trade, customs and immigration rules are tied up with the single market and a host of EU regulatory bodies.Ministers are seeking a legal deal to replace these with looser arrangements so we are outside the single market and customs union but keeping close ties so cross-border trade is easy.Negotiations under Article  of the Lisbon Treaty led to the withdrawal agreement in November - but MPs rejected it in January.Theresa May headed to Brussels on February  with fresh plans to fix the hated Irish border backstop.And the PM also jetted to Strasbourg on the eve of the March  meaningful vote, apparently in a bid to get further assurances from the EU.If Parliament cannot support a deal - and there is no extension - the UK will leave the EU without a deal on March .That would mean the UK being treated as a third country by the EU with commerce governed by World Trade Organisation rules, experts say.Some Brexiteers say that could be positive - opening up trade with the rest of the world - but many people fear chaos.On January , Boris Johnson said that a No Deal Brexit is the closest to what people voted for in the referendum.He also urged Cabinet Ministers to mirror the British publics optimism and self-confidence for the possible exit scenario.A poll by YouGov on January  revealed that  per cent of the British public think a No Deal Brexit is likely,  per cent think a failed deal will result in a second referendum,  per cent said the deal will pass and  per cent said a better deal could be negotiated.Eleventh hour talks for a new Brexit deal were on the verge of collapse this week as EU chiefs clashed bitterly with Cabinet ministers in Brussels.British and EU negotiators hit deadlock over a compromise on the Irish backstop.Brexiteers say it would be a boost for the UK to be free from Brussels rules and we will be able to strike deals with other upcoming nations around the globe.We would also not be obliged to pay the £billion orce bill, according to a House of Commons report — but Chancellor Philip Hammond sparked fury by saying we would pay up even without a deal.Many people fear the UK economy would be hurt by a clf edge Brexit as trade is held up by new border checks and tarfs and more red tape for businesses.Doom-monger Bank of England governor Mark Carney has warned house prices could crash by a third in a worst-case scenario.Customs checks on cross-Channel freight could cause havoc at ports, hitting food supplies and other goods such a motor parts.The Border Force is also planning for a possible No Deal Brexit as they fear there will be signicant outbound queues at the Eurostar and a degradation of border security, Sky News reported.In a pure No Deal Brexit scenario, businesses would lose their passporting rights, which allow them to sell their services across the EU without having to obtain licences in each inidual country.The  mile frontier between Northern Ireland and the Republic could become a hard border, according to Eurocrats in Brussels.The EUs rules may require Ireland to impose customs and other checks to protect the bloc’s border – which some say would mark ato the dark days of the Troubles.It could blow a hole in the Good Friday Agreement, with pressure on all sides to find a compromise.The Confederation of British Industry also said a No Deal Brexit would wipe £billion off the UK economy, making every region poorer, the Daily Mail reported.Theresa May has a Withdrawal agreement that has been negotiated with Brussels.But MPs rejected it when it was voted on in parliament in January.Mrs May suffered the biggest parliamentary defeat of any British Prime Minister when the Withdrawal agreement was rejected by a majority of .Another meaningful vote will be held tomorrow, March  - just over two weeks before Britain is due to leave the European Union.If Parliament reject the deal, they will then vote on whether to crash out with or without a deal on March .If MPs also reject a No Deal scenario, theyll then vote on whether to delay Brexit by extending Article .Parliament previously voted that May must seek alternative arrangements to prevent a hard border in Northern Ireland.Eurocrat Michel Barnier has tabled an offer that would allow Britain to quit the customs union rather than being trapped in the backstop.But the plan would see Northern Ireland staying tied to the EU - effectively creating a border inside the United Kingdom.Ministers announced plans for troops on the street and emergency ferries to cope with a No Deal Brexit.They will order businesses and families to start preparing for Britain to leave the EU without a deal and release £billion of extra spending.Ministers also unveiled the post-Brexit immigration system, which will end preferential treatment for EU migrants.Theresa May’s Government was plunged into utter disarray over Brexit just  hours before a crunch Cabinet meeting over Britain’s future.In December , Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt insisted Britain could “flourish and prosper”it story: NewsOfficials accused of cover up over cost of Boris Johnsons Afghanistan tripEXCLUSIVE: Officials blamed an IT issue after details of the embarrassing trip were slipped out to a member of the public while journalists responses were delayedShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR NewsBoris Johnson ing from his trip to Kabul "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOfficials have been accused of trying to “cover up” the cost of Boris Johnson’s trip to Afghanistan the day of a controversial vote. The former foreign secretary blew more than pound, of taxpayer’s cash on a visit to Kabul, which allowed him to miss a crunch vote on Heathrow expansion in June last year. Officials blamed an “IT issue” after details of the embarrassing trip were slipped out to a member of the public, while journalists’ requests were delayed. And following a six month battle, the Foreign Office was forced to admit they had internally identied requests from “known journalists”, breaking Freedom of Informationrules. And officials refused to reveal details of the ‘IT issue’ due to “national security” concerns. FOI expert Matt Burgess said: “Its outrageous, the law is meant to be applicant and motive blind. “This seems like a cover-up where the government is trying to hide information from journalists because they want an easier ride.”   He added: “Everyone should get the same responses to FOI requests, no matter who they are.” Shameless Mr Johnson travelled to Kabul on an last-minute visit on the same day he would have been forced to vote in favour of Heathrow expansion to keep his job. Mr Johnson once claimed he would lie down in front of the bulldozers to stop the poundbn plan for a third runway. Details of the trip were quietly disclosed to a member of the public in response to an FOI request. But they were not revealed to the Mirror and at least one other publication until a complaint was lodged, days later. The Foreign Office last night denied that it had deliberately held back the information from the media, or treated members of the press dferently to members of the public. But in emails dealing with the request, one official told colleagues: “I’m happy to clear these but can you provide a list of who they are from ”   Another email confirmed an official had “provided details of any known journalists.” The Information Commissioner’s guidance bans public bodies from dferentiating journalists from members of the public when dealing with FOI requests. It’s understood the Foreign Office did suffer an IT problem on the day the data was originally disclosed. But officials have been unable to explain why it affected some applicants and not others. And the department refused to make details of the IT problem public, saying it would be a threat to national security. A further request, for details of how the case had been managed by the Foreign Office, was delayed six time beyond its  working day time limit. Eventually the department revealed some of the information a full  working days late, without providing any explanation.

title: universal credit dwp should pay
story: NewsUniversal Credit: DWP should pay compensation for late payments, report declaresThe call is all the more striking because its been issued by a liberal Conservative aligned think tankShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR NewsThe major policy sht could have helped hundreds of thousands of people who have not received their first payment on time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Department for Work and Pensionsmust pay out compensation to families who receive their Universal Credit late, a report declares today.The major policy sht could have helped hundreds of thousands of people who have not received their first payment on time. As of February , a shocking % of Universal Credit claimants did not receive their first payment on time and in full. The standard waiting time for the benefit, paid to .million claimants and counting, is five weeks. The recommendation is made by the liberal Conservative-leaning think tank Bright Blue in a major report on reforming UC.  The groups report, Helping Hand  Improving Universal Credit, calls for an Independent Case Examiner to examine cases the DWP has handled wrongly. The case examiner could set standards for the DWP, such as delivering payment on time, as well as standards for the claimants. The amount of compensation issued to UC claimants should to some degree mirror the amount lost by claimants because of sanctions, Bright Blue said. Specically, the financial compensation offered to claimants as a result of non-compliance by DWP should be tiered according to the number of weeks a claimant has waited for their UC award. The Bright Blue report also recommended the DWP introduce a UC phone app and a live chat facility, and cap the number of claimants dealt with by each work coach.   The think tank said a certain amount of overpayments by the DWP should be disregardedthe government made the mistake. And it recommended a relaxing of the Minimum Income Floor, a cap on benefits for self-employed claimants that is currently being challenged in the High Court.  Ryan Shorthouse, Director at Bright Blue and co-author of the report, said: “Universal Credit has plenty of potential. A majority of claimants are coping with and adapting to Universal Credit. There are positive experiences with work coaches. And there are positive attitudes too: especially towards the single payment model and the use of conditionality. “However, as it has gone from idea to implementation, the initial widespread support Universal Credit enjoyed has dissipated. Despite welcome improvements made by the Government in recent years, there are too many examples and too much evidence of signicant hardship experienced by a sizable minority of those on Universal Credit.” A DWP spokesperson said: “We welcome the report’s finding that the majority of people have had a smooth move onto Universal Credit, appreciating the simple monthly payment and work coach support. “Universal Credit is a force for good, supporting over . million people. The majority of claimants are happy with the service and where challenges remain, we will continue to make improvements.”

story: NewsUniversal Credit: Up to , claimants moved to new regime without full supportSome .million people are now on Universal Credit - and its Director General has revealed "roughly half" of those joining are existing claimants in the benefit systemShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video universal-credit-new-regime-move-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA DWP chief tonight appeared to suggest around , benefit claimants have been forced onto Universal Credit without transition cash. Neil Couling, UC Director General, told MPs roughly half of those joining the six-in-one system are existing benefit claimants whose circumstances have changed. As of January this year, .million people were on UC.Existing benefit claimants who are moved to UC will have a transition fund to ensure their income doesnt drop, in a trial that starts in Harrogate this July and only rolls out fully in .But these protections do not apply to people whose circumstances change.   MPs have heard this so-called natural migration is triggered by changes in circumstances as small as a relationship breakup or a childs fth birthday.Labour MP Neil Coyle said the move was having a terrible impact on many peoples lives.Work and Pensions Committee chairman Frank Field said: People moving over are stranded. They dont have enough money.  In a hearing of the committee today, Mr Coyle asked what message the new trial sent to those who have already moved. He told Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd: What are we, five years in  And youre beginning a new pilot to see how Universal Credit works Independent Group MP Heidi Allen added: Its pushing people under the water. Ms Rudd replied to the MPs: It has always been the case thatyou change your circumstances and need to apply for new benefit, you may find that the situation of the benefits that are being proposed have changed. But Ms Allen said it was a problem hitting people whod moved two yards down the road. Asked how many people had had a change of circumstances, Mr Couling told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee: “It is hard to give a precise estimate. Because obviously it depends on the number of changes of circumstances that occur in a period, and that itself could be determined by economic and other factors. “But roughly it’s about half and half of caseload growth is through a change in circumstance - and half is through a pure new claim to benefit.  Policy in Practice warned % of UC claimants who move through natural migration lose out by an average of pound a week compared to the old system. Meanwhile % are expected to gain by pound a week, the think tank told the Commons Work and Pensions Committee.Asked to respond to the suggestion , people had moved through natural migration, a DWP spokesperson said: “Only new claimants or people who have undergone a change in circumstances are currently being asked to apply for Universal Credit .Where someone’s circumstances change it’s right that we reassess their entitlement to ensure they’re receiving the right level of support.” Ms Rudd admitted the initial rollout of UC, and the wait for payments, did I believe contribute to the growth of food banks” but insisted reasons are “ied”, and since the period she was talking about there’s been “vast improvement”. Meanwhile, Amber Rudd told MPs the four-year freeze on most working-age benefits will stay until March , but she expected it will end after that. I have private conversations with the Chancellor, she said.And she revealed the DWP have drawn up plans to hire extra staff in a No Deal Brexit .The Work and Pensions Secretary told a committee of MPs: “We have been making preparations for no deal planning. “We are making sure thatthere is an economic downturn, we are prepared to hire additional people should there be fewer jobs available as a result of a no deal exit.” She also confirmed reports the government overall has been looking at the possibility of a “hardship fund”there is no deal.

title: brit couple face 140k singapore
story: NewsBrit couple face £k Singapore hospital bill after mum suddenly gives birth earlyChloe Wilkinsons travel insurance did not cover the unexpected birth of little baby Lorcan during a stopover in SingaporeShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  MAR NewsThe couple were planning to tell their parents about the pregnancy once home - but little Lorcan wasnt waiting"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British couple stranded in Singapore face a poundk hospital bill after their baby was born premature at  weeks. Chloe Wilkinson, , and Patraic Walsh-Kavanagh, , were travelling back to the UK to tell their parents about the surprise pregnancy. But Chloe went into labour during a stopover in Singapore and gave birth to their son Lorcan, who weighed just .lbs. He is currently in intensive care and will have to stay in hospital for at least the next three months.    Chloe and Patraic took out travel insurance ahead of their once-in-a-letime trip, which began in December . But the policy didnt cover the unexpected pregnancy. Teaching assistant Chloe said: Lorcan’s been fighting with all his might and we are bursting with pride at the strength he is showing so far. “However, we are on our own, a  hour flight away from our family and friends, and it has been a very dficult start to parenthood whilst Lorcan remains in hospital.    Its still such a huge shock to us both that hes here but were doing everything we possibly can to ensure we all get back to the UK. Patraic added: We were in a complete state of shock and fear completely took over as we were faced with a severely premature baby with potentially multiple health issues whilst being stuck in a country with no support. “On top of this I was handed an estimated bill of poundk [, SGD] assuming there will be no further complications with Chloe or the baby. Teaching assistant Chloe and Patraic left the UK in December  to go travelling around Asia.    They then found work together in Australia before discovering Chloe was pregnant last November. The couple, who wanted to tell their parents the news in person, began flying home last month. But during a two-day stopover in Singapore Chloe was rushed to hospital after experiencing bleeding and cramps. Doctors told her she had started dilating at just  weeks - meaning flying home was no longer an option. Patraic, from Nottingham, East Mids, said: All the doctors and nurses seemed very concerned.   After numerous tests it was found that she had an infection so she was started on antibiotics and medication to reduce contractions and prolong labour to give baby the best chance of survival. However, Chloe, from Lincoln, fell more seriously ill and medics decided they had to deliver Lorcan immediately. She said: I was absolutely terried because I knew it was too early. When my water broke the room was quickly filled with doctors, midwives and paediatricians As soon as he was delivered he went straight into an incubator where the paediatricians started to help him breathe and stabilise him before whisking him off to intensive care. Hes fighting and doing his best but we feel so helpless.    Lorcan is currently in intensive care while his parents are living in a shared flat near the hospital. Their lack of working visas means they are unable to seek employment to support themselves. So the couple are trying to raise as close to pound, on GoFundMe to help pay for Lorcans hospital bills. By Monday afternoon they had raised more than pound,. Chloe added: Were professional people who work hard but its obviously a huge sum and anything anyone can offer to help would be greatly appreciated. We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone at home and across the world for their continued love and support. The travel insurer has been approached for comment.Anyone wishing to help the couple can visit their Go Fund Me page

title: distraught mums home invaded rats
story: NewsDistraught mums home invaded by rats as experts warn amateur poisons wont workLaura McQueenie, from Edinburgh, claims two rats have died in her kitchen sinkShareCommentsByArthur VundlaKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAR NewsMum Laura McQueenie has spotted rats throughout her flat "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught mum claims her home has been invaded by rats, as experts warn the rodents are immune to some poisions. Mum-of-three Laura McQueenie has been plagued by the germ-carrying animals at her council flat in Niddrie, Edinburgh, where she lives with her sons and young niece. The -year-old said the living conditions were disgraceful and describing overflowing bins as a health hazard. After the birth of her youngest son seven months ago, the social work student began to realise the scale of the problem. Laura said: Two rats have died in my kitchen sink and there are many more we have seen.   Every evening I hoover and sanitise all surfaces before bed. When I wake in the morning there are rat droppings all over the kitchen workspaces, window sill – they are even inside the bread bag. There are droppings all over the living room window sills, the floors. The young mum lives with her sons, aged eight, two and seven months, as well as her -month old niece. Laura said problems with rats were affecting the health of her youngest child - and said poison poured into the rodents’ holes did nothing to solve the problem. “The flat is absolutely disgraceful and it’s disgusting that we have to stay here because there’s nowhere  suitable for us. It’s been horric living here and it’s heartbreaking that I have no other option.   “I now go to my mum’s during the day because I can’t bear to be there. It’s filthy. The bins outside are a severe health hazard and I’ve been down with rubber gloves trying to clean some of it.” Pest control firm Wee Critters Pest Control estimated that there was a  per cent increase in call-outs year on year, while owner Sylvia Hill said amateur poisons bought by concerned residents would barely make a dference to the problem. Sylvia believes the Gorgie area of Edinburgh could be the worst in Scotland for rat infestations - and described the problem as a plague. She said: “We are struggling with the high demand at the moment. Ive had to share some of our jobs with other pest control companies. The city centre is full of rat problems but Gorgie is the worst area by far and possibly the worst in Scotland. We are honestly never out of there. Some of the problems are caused by laziness to be honest.   Rather than opening the bin lid to throw away the rubbish, people are leaving their rubbish and dog poo at the side of their bins.” She added: I have seen people buying amateur rat poison but although it may kill a mouse or two, adult mice and rats are hardly affected by it. The rats are just a major issue in Edinburgh at the moment. A total of , pest control requests were received by the City of Edinburgh Council last year with the Forth, Sighthill Gorgie and Craigentinny Duddingston wards proving to be the most problematic areas of the city. And there were , complaints about missed bin collections. However, although it appears that the rat population is increasing, the local authority said it had not experienced a signicant increase in vermin callouts. Cllr Lesley Macinnes, convener for Transport and Environment, said: We remain surprised by these comments and would be interested in hearing from the pest control firm, as this information goes against our evidence of what is happening in the city.

title: head teacher defends ban pupils
story: NewsHead teacher defends ban on pupils being given sweets on their BIRTHDAYSAmerican Chasey Crawford-Usher wasnt allowed sweets growing up and is alarmed by how much sugar British kids eatShareCommentsByHelena Kelly:,  MAR NewsOne Kent school is saying no to sugary sweet "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA head teacher insists she is not the fun police - despite banning children from bringing in sweets on their birthday.Chasey Crawford-Usher has also prohibited crisps and fruit juice from her school in Kent.The American-born teacher says she imposed the ban after being shocked by how much sugar British children were consuming. The self-confessed health fanatic insists the move is in the best interests of pupils.   She said: First of all, Im not the head teacher of all evil and saying no. Ive banned birthday sweets because they were becoming a huge problem in the school and mean the children were consuming processed sugar almost every day. Mrs Crawford-Usher, from New England, America, admits she wasnt allowed sweets growing up and claims her mother was a Whole Foods mum before it was trendy. She noted that children are provided with healthy and wholesome school dinners such as spaghetti bolognese, shepherds pie and roast dinners - all made with fresh ingredients.The strict head of Wateringbury Primary School also said desserts were on the table but they too were natural and unprocessed.  Despite the drastic measures, Mrs Crawford-Usher claimed students and parents have seldom complained. She said: People are angry about it for about a week and then it just becomes normal. I really havent had much of a backlash. Children can eat and drink whatever they want when they get home, I just want to provide them with healthier choices at school. The dental problems among schoolchildren now are awful and I want to do what I can to prevent it.   Its a terribly traumatic ordeal for a child to have their tooth extracted and its something I want to avoid. It comes after recent figures revealed ,  under-s needed tooth extractions last year. Public Health England estimated that youngsters were eating around eight more cubes of sugar per day than the recommended guidelines.However, Mrs Crawford-Ushers decision has come under fire on social media from Olympic race walker Tom Bosworth.He said: Again, common sense needs to be used here. Really what is happening to society to ban kids from having sweets on their birthday. - ban them every other dayyou like, but let a child be a child on their birthday though. The head hit back and said the Olympian had perhaps missed the point. She said: Yes, I think pupils should be able to eat sweets on their birthday buteach and every child brings them in to celebrate, the children would be eating them nearly every day. Also it puts an unfair pressure on parents to bring in sweets when perhaps they dont agree with them. Wateringbury CE Primary School is based near Maidstone, Kent.   Its mission statement reads: Our vision...to be an excellent primary school at the heart of the community where we inspire, excite and enable children to achieve. It was rated good in a  Ofsted report and Mrs Crawford-Usher said the obesity levels among pupils falls slightly below the national average. She has been head teacher of the school for eight years. And its not the first time the head teacher has cracked down on junk food.Last January Mrs Crawford-Usher banned the schools kids from eating crisps four days a week.  The school had previously banned sugary drinks like fizzy sodas and fruit juices too. Teachers are also encouraged to take pupils out of the classroom three times a week for a ten-minute run.Her drastic moves came after figures showed nearly one-in-five Year  pupils locally were classed as obese, with some areas of Kent leading the tables for older overweight primary school children.

title: how long you should keep
story: NewsHow long you should keep your sick child off school for each common illnessThe NHSs handy guide shows parents how long kids should stay home for - whether its flu, chicken pox or mumpsShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsIts important your child gets better - but also that theyre not contagious "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen your child gets sick, your first thought is for their welfare and recovery.If they are in school or nursery, however, its important to also consider the other kids theyll be coming into contact with.After all, kids do love to share - and this extends to colds, infections, viruses, you name it. So when is it OK to send your little one back to school, nursery or daycare  When are they contagion free  It largely depends on the illness which theyve been recovering from.Luckily, the Vale Royal CCG have put together the most common childhood complaints and advised for each when its safe to send them back to school.  Illnesses such as glandular fever, hand, foot and mouth, conjunctivitis, slapped cheek, head lice , tonsillitis and threadworms dont necessarily mean your child needs to stay home.However, the NHS does recommend you inform your childs school or nursery.The ones you do need to be mindful are as follows: Chicken pox - child canwhen all the spots have crusted over. Diarrhoea and vomiting -  hours from last episode. Impetigo - when lesions are crusted and healed or  hours after commencing antibiotics. Measles or German measles - four days from onset of rash. Mumps - five days from onset of swelling. Scabies - after first treatment. Scarlet fever -  hours after commencing antibiotics. Whooping cough -  hours after commencing antibiotics. Flu - until recovered.

title: madeleine mccann suspect seen carrying
story: NewsMadeleine McCann suspect seen carrying small girl is key to solving case, expert saysThe mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, on the night three-year-old Madeleine vanished in May ShareBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMadeleine was just three when she vanished in Portugal in May  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man seen carrying a small girl dressed in pyjamas on the night Madeleine McCann vanished is key to solving the case, an expert claims.The mystery man was spotted by an Irish family, the Smiths, who were holidaying in Portugal at the same time as the McCanns in May . The family would later claim they saw him carrying a girl, wearing pink and white pyjamas, down a quiet street around m from the beach. And US criminal profiler Pat Brown believes the sighting is the key in Madeleines case, which has yet to be solved more than a decade on. This is the number one issue about the whole case, and Ive stuck by this for years, and I stand by it today, she told  News in a podcast. Madeleine was just three when she vanished from an apartment in Praia da Luz, where she had been sleeping with her twin siblings.   At the time, her parents Kate and Gerry were dining with pals nearby.The reported sighting by the Smiths was at around pm on May , . The same night, a friend of Kate and Gerry also reportedly saw a dark-haired man carrying a child away from the direction of the apartment.But this sighting, by Jane Tanner, was reported to be  minutes before the Smiths one and was in a dferent location, the news site reports. Jane claimed she had gone for a walk when she saw, in the darkness and from some distance, a man carrying a child across the road ahead.“What makes the Smith sighting very interesting is that Jane Tanner is a friend, and the Smith sighting is a bunch of people that have no clue who the McCanns are, Pat, from Washington DC, says in the Maddie podcast.   These are not their friends. She adds: I believe the Smith sighting occurred. I believe they saw a man carrying a little girl down that road, which is towards the beach. E-fits of a suspect, based on evidence from holidaymaker Martin Smith and his family, were unveiled years after Madeleines disappearance.Meanwhile, an artist drew an impression of the so-called Tannerman - the man spotted by Jane, who was considered a suspect for years. Pats comments are made in the third episode of the podcast, which looks into the high-profile case and the two sightings that night.According to  News, the criminal profiler has studied the case in exhaustive detail, even flying out to visit Praia da Luz itself. Madeleine would now be , turning  in May this year.In November , Operation Grange, the Met Police investigation into her disappearance, was given a further pound, from the Home Office. This provided funding up to March  this year. The podcast is hosted by Australian journalist Mark Saunokonoko. A Netflix documentary about the case is set to be broadcast next month. Kate and Gerry earlier released a statement about the Netflix show. They said: We are aware that Netflix are planning to screen a documentary in March  about Madeleine’s disappearance.  The production company told us that they were making the documentary and asked us to participate.We did not see and still do not see how this programme will help the search for Madeleine and, particularly given there is an active police investigation, could potentially hinder it. Consequently, our views and preferences are not reflected in the programme. We will not be making any further statements or giving interviews regarding this programme.

title: meghan markle kate middleton exchange
story: NewsMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton exchange kisses as they arrive at Commonwealth serviceMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton joined the rest of the Royal Family at Westminster Abbey for a service to celebration Commonwealth DayShareCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience WriterSophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video kate-kisses-meghan-cheek-touching-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Duchesses of Cambridge and Sussex greeted each other with a kiss on both cheeks as they arrived at the Commonwealth Day service . Kate and Meghan joined the rest of the Royal Family , including the Queen , at Westminster Abbey for the celebration.The Sussexes, who are expecting their first child in the next few weeks, were first to arrive. Kate and William werent far behind them and the two royal women had a sweet reunion when they met inside the beautul abbey. They kissed each other on both cheeks, and both women did the same to their brother-in-law, just as Prince Charles and Camilla arrived.  Meghan wore a cream Victoria Beckham dress featuring a locks and chain pattern, teamed with a chic hat and green suede heels. Kate opted for a bright red knee- button down coat, beige heels and a Gina Foster hat.  The Queen looked lovely in purple with a stunning silver jeweled broach. She praised how the Commonwealth inspires its member states to find ways of protecting the planet and it citizens. In a written message, the monarch said: In April last year, I welcomed the leaders of our  nations to Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, and we all witnessed how the Commonwealth vision offers hope, and inspires us to find ways of protecting our planet, and our people.  We are able to look to the future with greater confidence and optimism as a result of the links that we share, and thanks to the networks of co-operation and mutual support to which we contribute, and on which we draw. With enduring commitment through times of great change, successive generations have demonstrated that whilst the goodwill for which the Commonwealth is renowned may be intangible, its impact is very real. title: pensioner one uks biggest collections
story: NewsPensioner, , caught with .million child abuse images jailed for  yearsGeoffrey Crossland, from Harrogate, North Yorkshire, also admitted storing prohibited firearms in a secret underground bunkerShareByHenry Clare:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSick Geoffrey Crossland has been jailed for more than  years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner who amassed one of Britains largest known collections of indecent images and stored guns in a secret bunker has been jailed. Geoffrey Crossland today admitted to storing prohibited firearms in an underground bunker at his home in Harrogate, North Yorkshire. When officers raided the sprawling Padside Green Farm property, they found guns hidden underneath it, along with ammunition. Police had been investigating the -year-old after he was found to have amassed more than . million indecent images. The horric pictures were described by the Crown Prosecution Service as one of the biggest known collections in England and Wales.  North Yorkshire Police said their seizure was the biggest in the county, and included , images in the most extreme category A. Appearing at York Crown Court earlier today, Crossland admitted  charges in relation to the possession of firearms and ammunition. He had previously pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images between January  and October . And this afternoon, the defendant was sentenced to  years and eight months behind bars by His Honour Judge Andrew Stubbs. Sentencing Crossland, the judge said: A search on your home led to the discovery of an enormous amount of indecent images of children.  In a locked box, devices and hard drives there was also a discovery of carefully stored images of many years dating back to . These were systematic searches, some of which found children between - being raped and others of young girls receiving a signicant amount of sexual abuse. Crosslands home was raided while he was holidaying abroad last year.He was arrested on histo Heathrow Airport in an operation conducted by police and the National Crime Agency . Stephen Wood, prosecuting, told the court: It [the bunker] was fitted with electrics and from there they recovered USBs, sim cards, external hard drives, laptops, computers, tablets, floppy disks and DVDs. Among the evidence there was a worrying document which had been created with login details so he [Crossland] couldnt forget which websites to access.  There was also websites on the documents listed with where he could access the best websites for indecent images of children and where he could share the information without being suspected. He even categorised the websites by the content and who had made them. Susannah Proctor, defending, said: The bunker at his home was made in  from storage containers which he applied for permission. He worked from his home at that time for his business creating manufactured electrical components. He possessed the firearms because he was an enthusiast and had been since he was  years old. This was also a hobby he shared with his father. Former businessman Crossland was jailed for five years for the possession of indecent images,  months for possessing moving images of a young girl, and six years for the illegal possession of firearms.  He was also issued with a ten-year Sexual Harm Prevention Order and placed on the sex offenders register for ten years. Detective Chief Inspector Graeme Wright, of North Yorkshire Police, was the senior investigating officer in the case. He said: This is without doubt the largest ever seizure of indecent images of children in the history of North Yorkshire Police. The investigation as a whole has been on a scale never seen before in our area regarding this type of offending. More than  digital devices were seized from an office area above the underground bunker complex on Crosslands premises. Each device had to undergo painstaking examination by North Yorkshire Polices Digital Forensic Unit supported by a team of specialist officers from the National Crime Agency.  There was also the recovery of the prohibited firearms and ammunition. We knew that Crossland had, legitimately, been an active member of shooting clubs over the years and he had acquired a large collection of firearms-related items and ammunition which he stored in the bunker. Nevertheless, everything had to be seized and carefully assessed to determine what was and what wasnt legally held. Marc Horsfall, of the National Crime Agency, said: A team of specially trained NCA officers spent several months working through Crosslands horric catalogue of abuse images to grade them in order of severity. Crossland and men like him are fuelling the actual contact abuse of children and the sickening distribution of those images. The NCA works with partners at home and abroad to catch child sex offenders and bring them to justice.

story: NewsMeghan Markle wears Victoria Beckham dress for second event as Kate stuns in redThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex were pictured beaming, hand in hand, as they arrived at Westminster Abbey this afternoon for a Commonwealth Day serviceShareCommentsByBradley JollySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video queen-meghan-kate-arrive-commonwealth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHeavily-pregnant Meghan Markle and husband Prince Harry have arrived at Westminster Abbey for the Commonwealth Day service. Duke and Duchess of Cambridge arrived at Westminster Abbey moments later for the Commonwealth event, to celebrate its  countries and . billion people. Meghan and Kate kissed each other on both cheeks and their brothers-in-law, just as the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall arrived. Kate, , was pictured in a knee- button down coat, beige heels and a Gina Foster pillbox hat.   Meghans Victoria Beckham outfit, a chic cream number, is believed to retail at more than pound,. The dress features prints of locked chains. The Queen has also arrived at the service. She complimented her purple outfit with a silver jeweled broach. In other pictures, Prime Minister Theresa May could be seen arriving at the abbey, wearing a feathered hat and a brightly coloured necklace.  She smiled and held on to her hat as she walked towards the abbey.The Queen today praised how the Commonwealth inspires its member states to find ways of protecting the planet and it citizens.In a written message, the monarch said: In April last year, I welcomed the leaders of our  nations to Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, and we all witnessed how the Commonwealth vision offers hope, and inspires us to find ways of protecting our planet, and our people. We are able to look to the future with greater confidence and optimism as a result of the links that we share, and thanks to the networks of co-operation and mutual support to which we contribute, and on which we draw.   With enduring commitment through times of great change, successive generations have demonstrated that whilst the goodwill for which the Commonwealth is renowned may be intangible, its impact is very real. Earlier today, Meghan and Harry had visited Canadas High Commission in London, where they got an insight into Canadian culture. The couple watched youngsters, whose parents work at the commission, making and eating Canadas quintessential sugary treat - maple taffy. Maple syrup was poured on to crushed ice and, as it hardened, the children rolled it onto a stick and quickly devoured the delicacy traditionally served at this time of year from sugar shacks in the woods.   After watching the youngsters and listening as Harry asked how many of these are you allowed , the Duchess tried making one for herself. She then gave it to nine-year-old Elodie-Rose Dugua-Inegbese. She added that it was signicant hosting the royal visit in the th anniversary year of the formation of the modern Commonwealth.   The high commissioner said: For me, the chance to have them here and focus on Canadian youth, withthe youth ambassador of the Commonwealth and the duchess, who has responsibilities with the Commonwealth Trust most newly, this is about the future of the Commonwealth, talking to the young people. story: NewsUK BB where cult teaches burping therapy to get rid of evil spiritsThe Lighthouse BB in a tiny Somerset village near Frome, is reportedly the UK meeting point for followers of Universal MedicineShareByLaura Forsyth:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video serge-benhayon-confronted-role-universal-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA socially harmful cult which has taught burping therapy to get rid of evil spirits is reportedly holding sessions at a bed and breakfast in Somerset. A civil court in Australia found Universal Medicine makes  claims about healing in a defamation case last December, according to the Sydney Morning Herald. It found that cult founder Serge Benhayon used bizarre forms of sexual manipulation and persuaded followers to shun loved ones who wouldnt join his cult. SomersetLive reports that the groups website say UK courses are presented at  The Lighthouse Accommodation and B  B in Frome, Somerset Serge has always denied running a cult and any wrong doing, saying he is the victim of a media witch hunt. story: NewsWoman has planned entire wedding and bought dress - despite not having a groomA woman has planned out her entire wedding, from the venue to the shoes but theres one major thing shes missingShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsTheresa Mahon has planned her entire wedding, despite being single "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa Mahon has already spent more than pound, on her dream wedding. Shes got the perfect dress all sorted, shes bought a sparkling tiara and she knows exactly what shade shade of pink her bridal bouquet is going to be.The only thing shes missing for her big day  Well, that would be the groom.The -year-old mum-of-three is single and hasnt dated anyone in three years, but that hasnt stopped her from spending the last year planning every single detail of her fairy tale Cinderella-themed wedding.  As part of this planning, Theresa, who lives in Dublin, knows the event will take place at a castle venue and Christina Perris A Thousand Years is going to be the song she and her husband have their first dance to - as shes been waiting for what feels like a thousand years to find the one.She also knows what food will be served on the day , what kind of shoes shes going to wearand that she wants to spend the honeymoon in Disneyland.And while some may think its odd to have so much planned without even being engaged, the mum disagrees, arguing that its sensible as there will be very little left to worry about when the time comes.  Her idea to plan the wedding was sparked when she and her partner broke up after six years of dating and having two kids together.The pair had discussed marriage, but sadly the relationship just didnt work out the way shed thought it would.Following the split, she decided she wouldnt let her lack of a prince charming stop her from getting on with her le and achieving her dream of getting married, so she started working out what she wanted. The mum admits that the wedding has become an obsession to her, but she is open to compromise when she finally meets the right man - though shes adamant the first dance song is not up for negotiation.  Theresa is also aware that some men may be put off by her grand plans, but shes hopeful that it wont put too many people off.Speaking on ITVs This Morning, she said: I can understand people are kinda gonna go oh God no, thats just too much too soon and I completely understand that.But Im not looking to marry someone within like the first six weeks of meeting them, like obviously you have to see how the relationship goes.While talking to Holly Willoughby, the mum also revealed her dream man would be a cheeky chap like Olly Murs, and she got a shock when he appeared on screen with a special message for her.Hi Theresa, its Olly here, Ive been hearing about your wedding day and its all planned and ready to go, he said. He continued: Im single, I hear that youre looking for the ideal man, youve said its me... right  He looked off screen and asked: Are we available that day  When the person said no, he replied that it was a shame.

title: how mafia boss snake who
story: NewsHow Mafia boss The Snake who once caught bullet with his teeth rose to powerCarmine Persico, , died in jail during a -year sentence this week for executing up to  people in a bloody war between New Yorks five crime familiesShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe mobster died during a -year prison sentence "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHe started his le of crime extorting lunch money from classmates and ended up the most feared of the old-school mafia godfathers. Along the way, Carmine “The Snake” Persico is suspected of killing  people and ordering hits on hundreds more, while surviving attempts on his own le – in one legendary incident by catching a bullet in his teeth.Now The Snake is sleeping with the fishes after dying in jail, aged , on Thursday.He grew up in the golden age of New York’s La Cosa Nostra, its five notorious crime families battling for supremacy. Persico wanted a slice of the action, dismissing his ft in stature and using his razor- sharp intelligence to rise to kingpin of the Colombo family, becoming known as “The Snake” as he double-crossed rival families to slither to power. And even after his luck ran out, and he was jailed for  years in , he continued to rule from behind bars, taking out contracts on those who dared to mess with the master.   He never broke the mafia’s Omertagrave, code of silence, and was “an old-school tough guy”, according to Frank Dimatteo, who grew up in the mob and co-wrote biography Carmine the Snake: Carmine Persico and His Murderous Mafia Family. Dimatteo says: “He’s a throwback to the real gangsters, not like these make-believe gangsters. You gotta give him respect for it.” Carmine John Persico Jr was born in Red Hook, Brooklyn, on August , . His father worked as a legal stenographer, but Persico idolised mobsters. As a kid, he was demanding his peers’ lunch money, as a teenager he formed the Garfield Boys gang. At , he was charged with killing a rival gang member, but the charge was dropped. By , he had been arrested for murder a second time.   He caught the eye of Frankie Abbatemarco, a member of the Profaci crime family – later to become the Colombo family – who hired him as an enforcer. He was in. But how to rise through the ranks  On October , , he was involved in one of the decade’s most famous mafia hits, the killing of crime boss Albert Anastasia, gunned down by the so-called “barbershop quartet” while getting a shave in the Park Sheraton hotel in Manhattan. No one was ever charged, but it’s believed Persico acted alongside one of the Gallo brothers, Crazy Joey. Later, when he learned kingpin Joe Profaci was creaming more cash than he should from his foot soldiers, Persico plotted with Gallo brothers, Joey, Albert and Larry, to take him out. Profaci caught wind of it, and bribed Persico to turn on the Gallos. On Profaci’s orders, Persico lured Larry Gallo to the Sahara Lounge in Brooklyn, and very nearly strangled him.   Luckily, for Gallo, a policeman walked in. Charges against Persico were dropped when Gallo refused to give evidence. The double-cross earned Persico his nickname The Snake, which he did not like. The Gallos tried to assassinate Persico, shooting him in the face. One of the bullets lodged in his mouth, but legend has it Persico spat it out and drove off. A few years later, he took revenge, killing Joe Gallo. When Profaci died of cancer, Joe Colombo replaced him, making Persico a “capo” in . Ten years later, Persico got to the top of the tree after Colombo was shot and paralysed. Michael Benson, who co-wrote The Snake’s biography with Dimatteo, says: “Carmine wanted to do just one thing with his le: be the leader of the gang, Top Cat. He acquired power the way other men breathe.”  Persico was in and out of jail throughout his tenure, but ran his operation from inside, making huge profits from loan sharking and racketeering. FBI wiretaps finally caught up with him and all five mafia families, resulting in the Mafia Commission Trial in the s. The Snake defended himself, and one judge said he was “one of the most intelligent people I have ever seen in my le”. He lost anyway and in  was put away for good for extorting millions. Seven others went down with him. An infection in his leg – for which he resisted amputation – and diabetes, ultimately led to Persico’s death at a federal jail in Butner, North Carolina. He leaves a we, two children, and  grandchildren. The Snake’s second nickname was “Immortal”, but, thankfully, it is only the legend that lives on.

title: look inside worlds fanciest mcdonalds
story: NewsInside one of the worlds fanciest McDonalds - and it even serves a very posh dishYou can walk into a McDonalds anywhere in the world, and changes are it will look very similar to the ones back home - all except the Freeport McDonalds in Maine that is...ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsIts very dferent to your average McDonalds "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPretty much everyone has been inside a McDonalds at least once in their lives, and lots of us go there a bit more than we probably should. Evenyoure not a fan of those delicious burgers, the fast food giants branding is absolutely everywhere so theres no avoiding it. Most of the companys thousands of restaurants look very similar, with the same decor, furniture and layout. But theres one branch in America thats very, very dferent. The Freeport McDonalds in Maine was built in a mansion once owned by William Gore, a prominent merchant in the town, reports Business Insider .   Not everyone in the town was happy about having a McDonalds there, so the company was only given the go-aheadbosses kept Gore House in keeping with the towns unique look. Speaking back in  Stephen Leroy, manager of the McDonalds media team, said: What we are doing there is something we probably have never done before in terms of design and the amount of time and effort involved. title: mum whose lunch kept getting
story: NewsMum-to-be whose lunch kept getting stolen at work catches thief and has her firedDont mess with a hungry pregnant womanShareCommentsByBlathin De PaorZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsElizaconceived again VERY quickly "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It doesnt matteryoure a CEO or an intern, having your food nicked from the fridge is an occupational hazard wherever you work .If youre lucky, this will only happen on a handful of occasions during your working le. Youll fume, perhaps resort to passive-aggressive labels, maybe even send a scathing email, but youll get over it. Imagineit happened to you every day, though For one mum-to-be this is exactly what was happening to her.Every day she took in a delicious homemade lunch created for her by her chef husband.Every day it got pinched from the fridge at work, RSVP Live reports.  She even explained that her husband would happily make the thief lunch, for a small fee. But while other colleagues took her up on this, the thief persisted. Then cameras were installed in the kitchen. She told Reddit: I began labelling my food hoping that would deter the thief. It didnt. Eventually, I put a note on the fridge that said: Please stop taking my food. I am pregnant and breastfeeding and this is negatively affecting my health.  The thief was a middle-aged woman who doesnt seem to like me. She is making triple what I am making,not more. After a week of thisI had the IT guy send me a screen-grab of her stealing, one from each day. Lunch Thief was up for a promotion. She’s near the executive level, and once you get this high up, the interviews involve execs from headquarters flying down to meet up with the execs in our office to sit in on presentations from the interviewees. The mum-to-be then admitted that she pinned up a photo of the lunch thief stealing her food.   Sheturned back to look at the screen in horror. The execs at my office who knew my lunches were getting stolen were visibly pissed at her. As it turns out, one of the execs who’d come from headquarters was also pregnant, and the other one had a we who’d just had a baby. She was terminated. It sounds cutthroat, but the woman reveals she never wanted it to go this far.  I didnt want her to get fired, I just wanted her to stop. If theyd ever talked to me, I wouldnt have wanted to get her fired. Aside from seeing the picture in the interview, they never involved me further. Never even asked me to send them the picture evidence for their own record.

title: woman 31 severe allergic reaction
story: NewsWoman, , has severe allergic reaction after performing sex act on boyfriendDoctors in Alicante, Spain, have now warned oral sex can cause anaphylactic shockShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  MAR NewsThe woman became unwell after forming a sex act on her partner [file image] "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman suffered a le-threatening allergic reaction after performing oral sex on her partner.The -year-old vomited and struggled to breathe after swallowing her boyfriends semen. She was rushed to hospital in Alicante, Spain, where doctors suspected shed gone into anaphylactic shock. The woman revealed she had an allergy to penicillin but denied having taken the drug, or any unusual foods, before performing fellatio. But medics at Hospital General Universitari dAlacant found her -year-old boyfriend had taken amoxicillin-clavulanic acid – a form of penicillin – to treat an ear infection before their sexual encounter. Its believed the case is the first of its kind ever recorded.British Medical Journal Case has now used the case as a warning to others.  Susana Almenara, lead author of the report, has urged anyone with known drug allergies to be aware of the potential risk and ensure they use condoms. We think that as clinicians it is important to be aware of this phenomenon so was to inform and prevent potentially serious reactions in sensitised patients. We also recommend condom use during treatment with drugs that can induce hypersensitivity responses in partners, she said. She added: This is the first case reported of a suspicion of amoxicillin-induced anaphylaxis in a woman after a sexual contact with a man who was taking the drug. The man, who also wasnt identied, took the medication four hours before having any sexual contact with the woman.   But his lover had to spend around one week recovering in hospital. She was given doses of adrenaline, steroids and salbutamol. Ms Almenara quoted figures from another study that showed around one in  penicillin treatments result in an anaphylactic shock. Writing in the journal, she added: We have detected some concern about this issue in consultations carried out by sensitive patients in internet forums. This concern on the part of patients is accompanied by a lack of scientic information around this question. Ms Almenara added even the smallest presence of an allergen, such as penicillin, in semen could lead to anaphylaxis.

title: world must prepare inevitable flu
story: NewsWorld must prepare for ‘inevitable’ flu pandemic, warns World Health OrganisationThe last flu pandemic was caused by the HN virus and caused between , and , deaths globallyShareCommentsByKate KellandSofia Petkar:,  MAR NewsThe World Health Organisation says the risks of a flu pandemic are high "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe World Health Organisation has claimed we are not adequately prepared for a global flu pandemic, with experts saying it “is a matter of when, not ”. In a statement issued earlier today, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus claimed the threat of pandemic influenza was “ever present”, warning the public not to underestimate the risks. He said: “We must be vigilant and prepared - the cost of a major influenza outbreak will far outweigh the price of prevention.” The last flu pandemic to strike was caused by the HN virus - also known as influenza A - that spread across the world during  and .   According to studies of that pandemic, at least one in five people worldwide were infected during the first year, and is estimated to have caused between , and , deaths globally in the same time. Global health experts and the WHO warn there is a risk that a more deadly flu virus will one day jump from animals to people, mutate and infect many hundreds of thousands of people. Flu viruses are multiple and ever-changing, and they infect around a billion people every year around the world in seasonal outbreaks.  Of those infections, around  to  million are severe cases, leading to between , and , seasonal flu-related respiratory deaths. Vaccines can help prevent some cases, and the WHO recommends annual vaccination - especially for people working in health care and for vulnerable people such as the old, the very young and people with underlying illness. The World Health Organisation’s plan - described as the most comprehensive to date - includes measures to protect the public as much as possible from annual outbreaks of seasonal flu as well as preparing for a pandemic. The plan’s two main goals are to to improve worldwide capacities for surveillance and response - by urging all governments to develop a national flu plan, and to develop better tools to prevent, detect, control and treat flu, such as more effective vaccines and antiviral drugs. During a pandemic, there is little or no pre-existing immunity towards the virus in the human population.  Three influenza pandemics occurred at intervals of several decades during the th century, the most severe of which was the so-called Spanish Flu”. It is believed to have caused an estimated – million deaths in –. Milder pandemics occurred subsequently in  and  known as the Asian Flu”, and the “Hong Kong Flu” in  - they caused an estimated one to four million deaths each.

story: NewsHindu man who mistakenly ate beef wants supermarket to pay for cleansing tripJaswinder Paul says his family havent talked to him since he ate a chunk of beef that he thought was lamb, and he needs to go home to India to be "puried" by priestsShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsHe bought the meat from a Countdown store in New Zealand "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Hindu man who claims he mistakenly ate beef labelled as lamb wants a supermarket to pay for a trip to India so he can take part in a cleansing ritual. Jaswinder Paul claims he bought a chunk of meat labelled lamb roast and was horried after discovering that it was actually beef. The barber didnt find out until after he had cooked it and eaten it - and he claims his family hasnt talked to him since. Mr Paul, from Blenheim, New Zealand, is now demanding the Countdown supermarket pay for a trip to his native India so he can be puried by priests after he broke his religious vow. Hindus consider the cow to be a sacred symbol of le. Mr Paul, who runs his own barber shop, told Stuff.co.nz: According to my religion, I have to go back to my country and do sacred things for four to six weeks, and be puried by priests, so I can continue on my religious path. Its a long process. Travelling to Delhi, he said, would require him to close his shop and pay thousands for flights, accommodation and food. Mr Paul said he complained to the supermarket and was offered a voucher as a goodwill gesture.   But he refused and asked the company to pay for his trip instead. That hasnt happened and he is not considering legal action as a last resort. He said: I understand this looks like a simple matter, but for me this is very hard. I break my religion [vows] because of someone s negligence. I know my society back from my home will not accept me with this breach of the religions conditions. It appears Mr Paul wont get his way. A spokeswoman for Countdown told Stuff.co.nz that an in-store labelling error resulted in a pack of beef mince being sold with both beef and lamb labels. She said the supermarket was sorry for the mistake and respects Mr Pauls beliefs, and that the goodwill gesture still stands.
