The first-ever footage of the Filin P- in use was broadcast on the Russian Defense Ministry’s channel Zvezda. It was filmed as the defence technology was tested in St Petersburg and shows the light flashing on and off continuously. One of the Filin P-s was said to be on board the Russias missile frigate Admiral Gorshkov which was spotted off the UK coastline last week.The Royal Navy scrambled a warship, HMS Defender, to follow the Russian naval task group, including the missile frigate Admiral Gorshkov.  HMS Defender intercepted the Russian vessels in waters north east of Scotland and escorted them as they passed the UK coastline and sailed through the English Channel. The Admiral Gorshkov, which is on its maiden mission, is alleged to have been fitted with the Filin P- visual optical interference weapon which can blind enemies and cause nausea, leaving them with feelings of disorientation and hallucinations. It is said the non-lethal weapon fires strobe-like beams to disrupt the enemys vision and prevent an attack, and is part of an arsenal that includes guided Kalibr missiles. Russias Ministry of Defence said the Admiral Gorshkov - named after Soviet Navy Admiral Sergey Gorshkov - is sailing with the supply ship Elbrus, the rescue tug Nikolay Chiker and the tanker Kama.   The Admiral Gorshkov entered service last year and is expected to join Russias fleet of ships in the Mediterranean. HMS Defender, a Type  destroyer equipped with a Sea Viper missile system, was scrambled over the weekend to keep watch on the Admiral Gorshkov and three auxiliary ships. The British warship left Newcastle on Saturday to head northeast of Scotland to meet the Russian task group in time for the ships to pass the UK coastline on Tuesday. A Navy spokesman said: Portsmouth-based Defender is monitoring the Russian task group and keeping track of their activity in areas of national interest.   Armed forces minister Mark Lancaster said: The Royal Navy is always standing ready to defend the UK. We will continue to work with our allies to shadow Russian ships passing through international waters close to our shores, to ensure the Russian navy follows the correct protocol on its journey. The Filin P- has also been installed on Russias Admiral Kasatonov frigate.

title: unforgettable moment premature baby twins
story: NewsMums tears of joy as premature baby twins embrace as theyre finally reunitedZoe and Olivia were born at  weeks and had to spend a month apartShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsIts been a really emotionally-charged time for the new parents "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tiny twins Zoe and Olivia spent  weeks together inside the womb before making their debut into the world.Having never been apart, however, it was at this point they were separated for the first time for a month to prevent one twin from accidentally suffocating the other. It took  days for doctors to be satisfied that the twins were strong enough to be reunited, and the emotionally-charged moment was made all the more poignant when Zoe reached out to hug her older sister. The decision to deliver the girls early was made after doctors were concerned that one of them was in distress.Mum Ann Les pregnancy had been a high-risk one, with her precious girls sharing an amniotic sac.Known as monochorionic monoamniotc twins, this sort of multiple pregnancy means there is only  per cent chance the twins will survive past  weeks.   Throughout her pregnancy from  week mark, Ann, from Melbourne, Australia, had had to have fortnightly ultrasound scans to monitor the girls development.On the day of their delivery, Olivia came first - with a loud cry, Ann tells Daily Mail Australia .Zoe came next but was breech, so after a bit of pulling, the doctor managed to get her out. She didnt cry or move which made us really concerned.  Both girls were quickly taken by the midwives to the paediatric team for assessment. Fast forward a month and Ann was finally able to have a much anticipated twin cuddle. We waited  days exactly for our first twin cuddle and it was so much more than we could have expected, she adds. Olivia was placed on me first, then when it was Zoes turn she reached out her left arm and hugged her sister. My tears were flowing, its a moment Ill never forget. The proud mum shared the beautul moment on Instagram .Now Ann is hopeful that she can take her girls home with her by mid-April. It has been emotionally draining for my husband and I, but now that they have passed the one month mark, their chances of survival are now greater than  per cent, she said.

title: Bags of help at North Kessock beach clean
story: A MAJOR Black Isle beach clean against the backdrop of one of the peninsularsquos most recognisable landmarks recovered  bags of waste, among it syringes, plastic and fishing lines.It is the fth time a group led by Greenpeace volunteers from Inverness has cleaned the beach at Scarabs at North Kessock near the Kessock Bridge.Greenpeace activists ldquoadopted the beach via the Marine Conservation Society with the idea of not only cleaning up on a regular basis, but also monitoring results over a longer period.David Smith, of Greenpeace Inverness, said: ldquoWe had a great turn-out which I think was due to online shares, it was really good to have so many people along.The community beach clean attracted around  volunteers, among them Highland Green MSP John Finnie.Mr Finnie said: ldquoIt was a very successful day. It seemed to be very well attended which was great as it felt like we were all part of a community effort.Mr Finnie went on to say that although these litter clean-ups were essential, the long-term goal should be to stop littering altogether: ldquoIdeally we want a situation where people are not dropping any litter. Prevention is better than cure.Among the litter picked up from the popular recreational area were six used syringes which Mr Smith believes were washed up rather than dumped there.A spokesman for Highland Council said: ldquoMost pharmacies offer a free needle disposal service. Failing that, people can put them in a safe container and take them to out to the waste management team at Lotland Street. Discarded needles should not be taken to recycling centres as they are classed as special waste.Greenpeace Inverness was established in October  and has supported the organisationrsquos national and global campaigns.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: Eastgate road closed as hostel demolition work begins
story: Motorists are being advised that Eastgate inInverness will be closed at its junction with Crown Road to its junction with Inglis Street from today until Friday.The closure is to allow demolition work to be carried out at the former Eastgate Hostel building which starts this week, more than five years after the fire that left it gutted.Pedestrian access remains open and access for emergency services and delivery vehicles will be at the discretion of the works contractor.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: High Life Highland boss retires
story: The chief executive of High Le Highland , the biggest leisure services provider in the region, has announced his intention to retire from the top job in the summer.Ian Murray has been the boss of the charity since it was created by Highland Council in October  when it was tasked with delivering and developing the local authorityrsquos culture, learning, sport, leisure and health and well-being services.Since then it has grown to employ more than  full and part-time staff and support more than  volunteers with an annual turnover of pound million.Mr Murray first moved to the Highlands  years ago to take up the position of depute director of leisure services with what was then Ross and Cromarty District Council.When Highland Council was formed in  he moved to the region-wide remit of head of community learning and leisure before leading the transition of those services to High Le Highland seven years ago.Mr Murray said: ldquoLeading the transition to High Le Highland and the seven years since has been the most challenging, rewarding and enjoyable period in my career.ldquoSince HLH began, visitor numbers have grown almost three fold, annual income has doubled, reliance on council funding reduced by half and HLH has been asked by the council and several community groups to adopt  additional services, from the formerly community-run pools in Bettyhill and Poolewe to more recently the councilrsquos school music tutor service.ldquoI have been very fortunate to have been supported throughout by a very motivated, professional and innovative team across everything we do.HLH was recently the centre of tensions over funding as Highland Council drew up its budget and sought to make cuts that saw the price of HLH membership rise by around pound. In draft budget papers, a move to increase the revenue target by pound. million was tabled but later removed.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: Second term for Inverness tourism business improvement district
story: Businesses have voted in favour of the Visit Inverness Loch Ness Tourism Business Improvement Districtcontinuing for a second term and a further five years, up to March , .Ballot papers were issued in January to  eligible voters and the count was held today with the result declared at Eden Court. businesses voted lsquoYesrsquo against  businesses which voted lsquoNorsquo.The BID area covers the Highland Council wards of Aird and Loch Ness, Inverness West, Inverness CentralInverness Ness-side, Inverness Millburn, Culloden and Ardersier and Inverness South.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Monday  Mar  : PM

title: sponsored tired of waiting weeks for appointments welcome to aberdeens newest walk in beauty salon
story: Fed up trying to book a nail, lash or brow appointment months in advance so you can get it at a time to suit you  Well, now there’s a solution, thanks to one of Aberdeen’s newest beauty salons.Lash and Lush opened its doors last month and for co-owner Jenna Young, it was vital that the salon suited its clients’ needs, not the other way round. vw, px"  “I’ve been a working mum for the past  years and it’s been so hard to get appointments, unless I booked weeks and months ahead of time.“But even then, with kids your schedule can be unpredictable so that always wasn’t the best way to do things.“I also thought that it would be good for a salon to be open on a Sunday, because people tend to have a bit more time on Sundays.”And in December Jenna decided it was time to make her wishes a reality for other women in Aberdeen.Just over a month later Lash and Lush was up and running. vw, px"  Open six days a weekpeople can just turn up and get treatments.“We don’t take appointments, it’s walk in only, which means you don’t need to wait weeks for an available space.”The team of four highly experienced beauty therapists offers nails , eyelash extensions and volumising, and eyebrow waxing, threading, tinting and henna brows. vw, px"  “Henna brows are a natural way to create a new shape of an eyebrow, or to enhance eyebrows that are pale or have gaps.“And until the end of the month, you can get henna brows for just £.”Jenna added: “Each member of the team focuses on dferent treatments, but every one of them works hard to give customers the look they want.”Lash and Lush is open from am until pm on Tuesdays and Wednesdays and pm on Thursdays and Fridays. On Saturdays they open at am and close at pm and between am and pm on Sundays.Find out more about Lash and Lush on their Facebook page.

title: aberdeen gardening group calls for botanical enthusiasts
story: A popular gardening group is encouraging green-fingered folk to take part in its competition.The Royal Horticultural Society of Aberdeen will host its spring show on March  and .Held at the Winter Gardens in Duthie Park, people across the north-east are invited to showcase the flowers and plants they are most proud of.Hazel Main, secretary of The Royal Horticultural Society of Aberdeen, is encouraging people to participate.There are four dferent categories, which include spring flowers, floral art, plant stall, and bric-a-brac – an elaborately decorated flower exhibition.Hazel said: “There really is something for everyone from the youngsters upward in the schedule.“Entries have to be staged by pm on the Friday night.“Judging takes place on Saturday morning and the show opens at .am.”The presentation takes place at pm on Sunday.”The society also hosts a summer show at the Victorian park’s gardens every year.In addition to the shows, the group organises a series of gardening workshops for amateurs or beginners.Those interested in competing in the spring show can email entries in to Tracey Keith at rhsaberdeen@hotmail

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. title: a picture of the past written in argylls records
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt least until Elon Musk builds his time machine, the vast archives held in Argyll are the best way to get an idea of le in the region#s past.A Lochgilphead audience got a flavour of some of the material within two of Argyll#s most extensive and fascinating collections of documents when a roadshow arrived in town to showcase the #Written in the Landscape# project.At Lochgilphead Community Centre, archivist Jen Young outlined the type of archives held by the Live Argyll trust for Argyll and Bute Council including title deeds, personal correspondence, educational records and the history of societies and organisations.Jen has had the task of uncovering and cataloguing  dferent collections of records from landed estates and businesses across Argyll and Bute going back hundreds of years.Co-presenting the event was Hannah Baker, an archivist working on the Written in the Landscape project within the Argyll Papers archive # the documents of the Dukes of Argyll and Argyll Estate dating back to the th century.Within this rich deposit lies a vast source of information. Documents such as rent records, estate census papers, military papers, letters, maps and legal documents can offer a glimpse into the lives of people who lived across Argyll.The two-year Written in the Landscape project is set to wind up in July this year and has entailed cataloguing and digitising the Argyll Estate and other records to make them more accessible to the public.As Hannah and Jen travel round Argyll on their tour, the intention is to offer a local flavour from the archives aimed at each venue.For the Lochgilphead workshop on February , Jen and Hannah presented such erse items as #registers of the poor# and burgh court rolls from Lochgilphead, th century wage books from Kilmory Estate alongside military commission documents from the th century and a  map of the proposed Crinan Canal, surveyed by John Rennie.Each record offers a dferent insight among a treasure trove of detail.The Lochgilphead presentation followed a similar event in Campbeltown in January. Workshops will be held in March on Mull, Helensburgh in April before travelling to Strachur, Dunoon, Inveraray and Tiree in May.Further information on the Argyll Paper records can be obtained by emailing archives@inveraray-castle. For more information on the Argyll and Bute records, contact archives@liveargyll.PICS:Jen, left, and Hannah with some of the records on display in Lochgilphead. aArchivetalkA  letter from Neill Malcolm of Poltalloch offering to call up tenants to defend Crinan Bay against #the enemy# # presumably the French. aArchivetalk

Just about visible across Loch Gilp is the Scottish Canals-led Egg Shed project to create a new heritage and interpretation centre in Ardrishaig, due to open this summer.And the council is bidding for funding worth more than £ million through Historic Environment Scotland#s CARS scheme to refurbish some of Lochgilphead#s town centre buildings.Add to that planned improvements to public halls and the KGV pitch in Ardrishaig planned upgrades at Mid Argyll Community Pool a major project by Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and more, it is clear things are happening in Mid Argyll.If you want to give your thoughts on what should feature in the front green project, there will be a drop-in event between am and pm at the corner of Colchester Square and Poltalloch Street where you can meet council staff and members of the design team and ask questions, hear about the plans and give your views.An Argyll and Bute Council spokesman said: #We want to work with the community on the plans for delivering improvements to the front green and Colchester Square, so please come along for a chat and a cuppa.#A second event will be held on Saturday April , when people will be able to see how the plans have developed based on comments gathered this weekend.Design team member Nick Wright said: #This is a great opportunity for folk to come and share ideas about how to make the front green into a space that the community is really proud of.#We’ll have some ideas to start people thinking, but we want to hear what people’s ambitions are for the space.#That could be anything: stopping flooding, more events, a nice place to sit, more exciting play areas or something to make tourists stop and spend time in the town. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: bob sheilds make new recycling
story: NewsBob Shields: Make new recycling system in South Ayrshire work for usNew leaflets needed to inform the publicShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter a first glance at last week’s report on noisy bin men – I had to check out my calendar to make sure I wasn’t getting a month ahead of myself. Let’s face it, stories about a Mr Paine and some broken glass usually appear on April . But no – it really was only March ! Mr Paine’s issue is the emptying of his street’s bottle bins at am. On the morning of his first collection, he mistook the noise of breaking glass for a robber breaking into his house. “I was terried,” he said. And then added, “This is noise pollution and most of the street must have been up.” Well, I too have suffered Mr Paine’s ‘noise pollution’ - perhaps an even noisier version. Chez Shields is no stranger to a well chilled Petit Chablis washing down the foie gras before Eastenders. In fact, I’ve been known to pop a second cork just to recover from Eastenders! Based on Mr Paine’s video recording, the noise made by the emptying of my bottle bin is right up there - somewhere between a small public house and a decent sized restaurant. Andit wakes up my neighbours – I couldn’t give a Chateau Le Clos! On my street’s first collection, I didn’t wake up thinking I was being burgled. House-breakers don’t usually make enough noise to get “most of the street up”. I seem to remember thinking, “That’ll be the bin men . . .” and going back to sleep. And on the  days a year that the glass bins are emptied in “quiet, residential Masonhill”, I respectfully suggest Mr Paine does the same. After all, we’re talking about saving the world here . . . not saving an hour’s kip! Greenhouse gas emissions are asphyxiating the planet. Plastic bags are strangling dolphins and milk bottle caps are choking sea birds. Our little Earth is throttling itself. To be honest, I’d rather be concentrating on ten decades of industrial pollution than Mr Paine’s ten minutes of noise pollution. And meanwhile, still in bin land, South Ayrshire Council is blaming the public for the latest waste collection problems. I can see the point they’re making – but the word “contamination” is a bit strong for Mrs McGuffie putting Tiddle’s empty Whiskas can in the paper and cardboard bin. And the new recycling system is a little too new for the “red tag” bin police to be targeting offenders. By refusing to lt certain bins – South Ayrshire Council is tempting fate. I’ve heard reports of some people using a neighbour’s bin when their own bin is full and red tagged. I’m also told there are increasing incidences of household waste being stuffed in the street bins reserved for pedestrian litter. And stuck in the middle are the bin men themselves. One told me “If we red tag a bin – we get **** from the householder. If we take back a contaminated bin, we get **** from our supervisors. Basically, were in the **** no matter what we do!” My dear old mum used to use a lovely phrase – “There’s a place for everything . . . .and everything in its place”. That’s exactly how SAC’s new recycling system meant to work. But it’s going to take a little time and a little patience – on both sides. The info leaflets sent out to explain the new system were largely ignored or discarded - most people didn’t understand them. But with the new bins now rolled out – a back-up leaflet might help. “You’ve got your new bins – now here’s how to use them”. Rubbishing the new rubbish system isn’t going to make it go away. It’s here – let’s get on with making it work for ourselves, our neighbours and our community.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironment

title: churches facing end era parish
story: NewsChurches facing end of era as parish minister calls it a dayCrisis in Kirk conregationsShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email There’s no parish ministers round here, writes Edwin LawrenceThat’s the crisis facing Kirk congregations in Girvan and South Carrick. And it becomes reality with the imminent departure of Rev Richard Moffat from Girvan North Parish Church. The area – in the short term at least – will be dependent on the services of elderly retired ministers and lay readers. Mr Moffat has been a popular parish minister at Girvan North for five years. And he was due to become Moderator of the Presbytery of Ayr in April. But he is set to move to a new charge in Morayshire, to be closer to his daughter and her family. He will conduct his last Sunday service in Girvan North on March . Mr Moffat’s departure is the latest factor concentrating minds in the Church of Scotland. For Girvan South, linked with Barr and Dailly is currently without its minister. Popular Rev Ian McLachlan has been on sick leave for several months. And colleagues say he is unlikely toto full-time duties. Rev Stephen Ogston was parish minister at Ballantrae Colmonell from  until August, . But he moved on to Luce Valley Church, and no replacement has been found. The linked charge of Ballantrae St Colmon also takes in services at Barrhill and Glenapp. So communities right across Girvan and South Carrick no longer have a parish minister in their midst. And there is uncertaintly at how things will be resolved. One solution might be a union of the two Girvan churches. And that could leave Girvan North - with its -foot spire – as the last kirk in town. It would presumably also be used as a hub to minister to village churches. The Post understands there can be as few as six worshippers in Barr Parish Church on Sundays. This isn’t helped by Barr being last in the pecking order for services, after Girvan South and Dailly. So it’s virtually lunchtime before a Sunday service gets under way. A Presbytery of Ayr meeting was due in the Carrick Centre in Maybole on Tuesday this week.And the Post understands this will see Rev Ian Stirling Fisherton Kirkoswald appointed interim moderator at Girvan North. Locum minister will be retired minister Rev Edgar Ogston – father of Stephen – who livesin Girvan.The Post has spoken to kirk elders in Girvan who say they’re uncertain about the future. And a retired church minister suspects that the two Girvan churches will be required to amalgamate. He said: “Things are changing. We’ve been a clergy-centred church for  years. “But one positive thing we’re seeing is the rise of worship groups which are prompting people to think about their faith, without necessarily being preached at.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnChurch of ScotlandAyrMoffatGirvan

title: college staging wine fuelled feast
story: NewsCollege staging wine-fuelled feast as job cuts loomLeaked emails tell of lavish bash at cash-strapped Ayrshire CollegeShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCollege bosses have defended holding a celebration to honour their success amid a climate of drastic job cuts and cash problems. Ayrshire College supremos and invited senior staff will stage a sit-down feast later this month to mark five years since its formation. The dinner for  will also include free wine after a sponsored deal by college chairman Willie Mackie. Leaked emails state the claim the college is “now regarded as one of the most successful colleges in Scotland.” But our inside source said: “It adds insult to injury that this celebration is being held less than one week before the final jobs structure is issued to staff. “It is in extremely poor taste given the circumstances of potential job losses due to lack of funds.” Evening classes are having to be cancelled so the event can be staged at the Kilmarnock campus on March . Retiring principal Heather Dunk is also to be honoured during the evening. Chairman Willie Mackie said: “She has made a signicant contribution to Ayrshire for over  years.” Ms Dunk retired on February , leaving an impending restructure which will cost jobs. A consultation ends tomorrowand it has emerged the Private Finance Initiative which built the Kilwinning campus is a huge drain on funds. An email which Ms Dunk sent to staff in January read: “We need to make signicant savings to be financially sustainable due to the costs associated with the PFI, unfunded national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and other services. I am very disappointed that an organisational review is necessary, it is not what I want to be focused on in my last weeks as principal. “However, we must manage within the financial allocation we receive in this very dficult fiscal climate.” Under the consultation, one of the four vice-principals would be axed, three directors culled, heads of learning cut from  to nine, and three marketing coms staff would go. Also at risk of the chop are two posts within estates as well as a shake-up of duties among departments. The board of management will approve the final structure and staff impacted will get a severance package. Ayrshire College acknowledged finance was a major challenge for all Scottish colleges but said the dinner costs were met by sponsorship. A spokeswoman said: “Our main financial challenge for the year ahead is to meet the costs associated with the Kilwinning PFI Campus, national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and services. “While the Scottish Funding Council has agreed to provide further strategic funds to help manage these rising costs, the college still requires to make signicant savings to secure its financial sustainability and jobs for the future. “We are, therefore, considering proposals for an organisational review. “All staff are aware of the challenges the college faces, and have contributed to a consultation regarding potential efficiencies and opportunities for income generation. “We have just passed our five-year anniversary as Ayrshire College, and have planned an event, ‘Celebrating Five Years of Success. It is important to recognise this milestone and celebrate success – for learners, staff, the college and the region. “We are mindful of the costs of holding such an event and so have secured full sponsorship.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnUniversities and CollegesAyr NewsAyrEducationKilmarnockSchoolsKilwinning

title: first minister must act over
story: NewsFirst Minister must act over Tarbolton landfill, says MSPThe South of Scotland Tory MSP says he is hearing growing concerns from villagers about the condition of the site.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsBrian Whittle MSP challenges the First Minister in the Scottish Parliament "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than eight months after Tarbolton Landfill’s owners entered liquidation, MSP Brian Whittle has challenged the First Minister to act, writes Edwin Lawrence. The South of Scotland Tory MSP says he is hearing growing concerns from villagers about the condition of the site. He said: “Since the landfill closed its gates, worries have been expressed about smells and also about contaminated water running off the site.” These would normally be dealt with by the site owner, so Mr Whittle took up the issue with both the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyand the Scottish Government. However, in the absence of a clear answer on ultimate responsibility, he decided to raise it at Holyrood, during First Minister’s questions. In response, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said:   “I am not able to give that information to Brian Whittle right now. “I undertake to raise the issue with the environment secretary and to come back to Brian Whittle as quickly as possible about our understanding of the lines of accountability and the action that the Scottish Government can take to try to reach a resolution of what certainly seems to be a deeply unsatisfactory situation. “I can understand that people in the local area will be very concerned about any prospect of contamination and it is absolutely necessary that all relevant agencies and organisations respond as quickly as possible.” Speaking afterwards, Brian Whittle MSP said: “The situation with the Tarbolton Landfill has been allowed to drag on for too long already. “Aside from the obvious concerns local residents have, it’s troubling that there doesn’t appear to be a clearly defined process for when the operator of a site like this is no longer able to carry out their duties to protect the surrounding environment. “I hope the First Minister will be able to provide some much needed clarity on this issue.”

title: giant bins placed right outside
story: NewsGiant bins placed right outside a restaurant and pub in scenic townAnger in Troon as bin squad set up town corral without asking anyone for permissionShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA council works gang put up a new big bin enclosure – right outside a restaurant and pub in the scenic centre of town. Now a row has broken out after it emerged one council department had not even bothered to speak to another. The unsightly corral cluster for five bins was secured in place near The Cross in Troon without any consultation. Troon Councillors have now become aware after a multitude of complaints. The cleansing department is claiming they contacted the planning department about the placing of the bins. But planners are denying any knowledge of a consultation. Troon SNP Councillor Craig Mackay is now leading the charge to find somewhere  for the bins to be situated, rather than outside the Jade Garden Chinese and Macintyre’s bar. He is asking for officials to meet councillors at the spot in Templehill to try and find a resolution. Councillor Mackay said: “We are trying to develop a coherent vision for our town centre. “I’m not convinced this is the best we can manage for such a high profile location. Cleansing regrettably installed these enclosures without any prior consultation. While it is arguably an operational matter that doesn’t require any such input,they had asked any of the councillors or the community council for comment then I am certain we would not have found ourselves in this situation. “The council’s Planning service disappointingly also appear not to have been consulted on the siting or design of this bin store within the conservation area. I don’t wish to play departments off against each other, but would seek to find a community consensus about what is appropriate for our public realm. “This will almost certainly involve an alternative solution for the bins.” A council spokesman confirmed they are investigating, saying: ““We introduced communal bins to keep the litter secure and away from gulls. The early indications are that this system is working well, however we are currently reviewing the location of the bins.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnScottish National PartyTroonAyrAyr News

title: look out sooty sweep heading
story: NewsLook out, Sooty and Sweep are heading to AyrStage show insists laughs will come thick and fast at Ayr GaietyShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSooty is set to SWEEP into Ayr next month. The wee silent man will be on stage with his squeeky pal Sweep and chatterbox Soo. TheirRichard Cadell will lead events at The Gaiety in Ayr on April . It’s being billed as a brand new Laugh Out Loud Magic Show. Sooty takes to the air in a flying car, Soo has a singing unicorn and Sweep has something altogether dferent. He has a levitating sausage, which certainly creates a vision. Special guests circus star Michael Jordan and the ultraviolet specialties of Fantasie de la Nuit promise a thrilling -minute show. Tickets are between pound and pound and there are two shows – am and .pm. Sooty has celebrated his th birthday and Richard says he’s still as young as ever. Richard revealed: “This show is Sooty doing what he does best – magic. “So the Gaiety audience can expect to be saying ‘Izzy whizzy let’s get busy’ a great deal. “Sooty will be performing some amazing tricks including sawing a lady in half, floating a child from the audience and making it snow. “Sweep will be getting in the way with his own disastrous magic tricks most of which revolve around sausages.” He added: “Performing live is what we love most. Of course, making the television show is a lot of fun but Sooty has always been at his best in front of a live audience where he can make not only the children laugh, but all the adults too. Plus after each performance there is a chance for everybody to meet Sooty and it’s always such a pleasure to meet fans old and new.” Sooty and Sweep performed for Prince Charles for his th birthday. Richard added: “I think it was possibly the highlight of Sooty’s career. It was just an amazing experience to be there at the London Palladium at the request of Prince Charles. “It turns out that Sooty and Sweep have always been personal favourites of the Prince. We also received a lovely personal letter saying how much he had enjoyed Sooty and Sweep’s performance. story: A NEW campaign has been launched to encourage people to get checked for cancer.With research highlighting that fear of a potential cancer diagnosis continues to stop people acting, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Survivors campaign aims to illustrate that more people are surviving cancer than ever before, and highlight that getting checked early plays a big part.People are being encouraged to join the movement by sharing what a loved onersquos cancer survival has meant to them, using #MySurvivor in a bid to tell the other side of the story.For more information visit getcheckedearly.org.

title: biggest-parents-evening-comes-to-the-borders
story: A pathway organisation that helps school pupils in the Borders find careers and jobs is hosting the Biggest Parents Evening in Galashiels this week.Developing the Young Workforce Borders are one of  regional groups working in partnership with local employers to showcase apprenticeship and career opportunities as part of Scottish Apprenticeship Week.The local DYW Borders event will be held at Job Centre Plus, Galashiels on Wednesday .The live jobs fair features full-time, part-time and apprenticeship opportunities as well as a CV workshop and information on the SQA Qualications and the apprenticeship family.Sara Ward, Programme Manager with DYW Borders, told us: "The event will provide an understanding of the apprenticeship family while getting rid of the myths and misconceptions."Hosted in partnership with Skills Development Scotland, Borders College and Jobcentre Plus the aim of the event is to promote the fantastic local career opportunities and help parents and carers understand why they should encourage more young people in choosing an apprenticeship in the Scottish Borders."National and local organisations who have already signed up to promote their opportunities at the Biggest Parents Evening include NHS Borders, Oregon Timber, Scottish Borders Council, Works+, McDonald Cardrona Hotel, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, Mears Group, Encompass and many more.Sara added: "The event will not only demonstrate a clear commitment from employers to showcase the great opportunities that are available locally but raise the profile of those committed to Developing the Young Workforce."We are very aware that parents are the biggest influencers in a childrsquos career path, therefore we aim to influence the influencers."The event, which runs from pm to pm, is open parents and pupils

title: jim-clark-rally-could-return-this-spring
story: ORGANISERS of the Jim Clark Rally are confident the race willto the roads of the Borders this spring.And they have pencilled in the weekend of May  and .The rally has not taken place since the tragic deaths of three people in .Elizabeth Allan, , Iain Provan, , and Len Stern, , were all killed as a car left the road near Coldstream.Major reviews have since taken place into safety surrounding closed road rally events as well as a fatal accident enquiry.The Scottish Government is now looking at afor both the Jim Clark Rally and the Isle of Mull Rally by bringing legislation into line with the other parts of the UK.A spokesman for the Jim Clark Rally told us: "We have been maintaining contact and continued working with Scottish Borders Council and Police Scotland in hopeful anticipation that rallying couldsooner rather than later."Arrangements and plans are already in place to facilitate a quick resumption of the sport on completion of the parliamentary process."Potential rally competitors, officials, volunteers and fans right across the UK are therefore advised to pencil in two important dates, May  and  , and plan their routes to the eastern Scottish Borders."With a bit of luck and goodwill, it should soon be possible to allow all those interested to confirm their diary date in ink."The recently concluded Public Consultation by the government on the new proposals proved there was an overwhelming desire for awith  percent of all replies being positive.

title: extending-borders-railway-among-21-options-to-improve-transport
story: EXTENDING the Borders Railway line and putting on extra buses to the BGH are two of the options being considered to help shape the future of transport in the region.In a report published today, The Borders Transport Corridors Study outlined  options that could bring benefits to the area.And they include proposals for better bus links to health centres and neighbouring cities as well as the partial dualling of the A and A roads.Cabinet secretary for transport, infrastructure and connectivity Michael Matheson said: "The Borders Transport Corridors Study fulfils our commitment to consider the future transport needs of the area."We have already committed to rail stations at East Linton and Reston and these will be delivered as part of work to improve capacity to Edinburgh. We will now go on to consider a further twenty-one options as part of the Strategic Transport Projects Review , which is being taken forward during the letime of this Parliament.ldquoThe Projects Review is a nationwide appraisal to identy where improvements are needed and guide investment in Scotlandrsquos transport infrastructure over the next two decades."The recommendations made in this study ndash which are underpinned by detailed evidence on problems and opportunities ndash will help ensure the case is made for improvements in The Borders."We look forward to building on the successful partnerships that we have developed as part of the study as we move forward with the next stage of this important work."

title: galashiels-shows-sweet-charity-love
story: SWEET Charity may be about a down-on-her-luck dancehall hostess searching for love.But there was certainly a lot of it coming from the Volunteer Hall audience at the end of Galashiels Operatic Amateur Societyrsquos opening show on Monday night.Led this year by Carla McColgan, the group put on another faultless performance. The story focusses on protagonist Charity Hope Valentine who is desperate to find her Mr Right.She works at the seedy Fandango Ballroom but has dreams of moving on to bigger things.But it may eventually be the performers themselves who reach the top ndash as their talent shone all evening. In the opening scenes Carla, Jan Bairdand Ruth Davidsonwowed the sell-out crowd with their renditions of classics including You Should See Yourself and Big Spender.And just when it looked as though Charity may have found the one when she meets Italian film star Vittorio Vidal, played by Jack McAulay, she ends up spending the night in his closet as his partner Ursulas home.The cast mastered their American accents, while Jackrsquos Italian twang seemed second nature. And he also impressed with his powerful performance of Too Many Tomorrows.Charity however gets her second chance when she gets stuck in a lt with Oscar ndash a claustrophobic accountant hilariously played by Clark Eaton Turner.Clark is no stranger to the Volunteer Hall stage, and it is clear that the versatile actor can turn his hand to anything. Everything looks well for the dance hall hostess, as Oscar proposes.But the wedding plans are dropped ndash and Charity has to find happiness within herself.On an evening of such commanding performances, it can be easy to forget the people who also work so hard behind the scenes to create this spectacle.Producer and musical director Jeff Thomson deserves huge credit as does choreographer Marie McCullough who obviously worked tirelessly.The sets are brilliantly designed and the scene-changes are swt. The orchestra was also given a deserved ovation at the end. There wasnrsquot a note out of place.Sweet Charity is running this week at the Volunteer Hall, Galashiels, until Saturday, March .
